0.cdata!: Promouvoir une bonne alimentation au Bangladesh

topicv3: Health Facility Management m1326575 1397,Health Equity and Access m1326151 1288,Health Economics and Finance m1326577 625,Nutrition m1326779 644,Nutritional Programs m1327441 1614

abstracts.cdata!:
Malnutrition levels in Bangladesh remain
            the highest in the world, providing the starkest evidence of
            the barriers to its economic and social development. In
            1995, the government launched the Bangladesh Integrated
            Nutrition Project (BINP) with support from United Nations
            Children's Fund (UNICEF) and a 59.8 million dollars
            credit from the World Bank. By the end of 2001, the project
            had reached more than 3 million households in over 13,000
            villages across Bangladesh, providing services such as child
            growth monitoring and food supplementation for those most at
            risk - children under the age of two, women who are
            breast-feeding, and pregnant women. In 2000, the World Bank
            approved another 92 million dollars for a broader-reaching
            national nutrition program, aimed at expanding
            community-based nutrition services and activities. This new
            initiative is seeking to ensure diverse and nutritious food
            is provided to a group comprising nearly one-third of the
            Bangladeshi population.
